name: Pete

topics.topic_text: GREETING
topics.response_text: You're back. When you walked off in the middle of our people's story, I thought you must be bored.

topics.topic_text: VEndingBoomers
topics.response_text: {Narrating}Without organized leadership, the remaining Boomers slowly drifted away, leaving Nellis Air Force Base to be flooded by prospectors and scavengers.

topics.topic_text: Who are you?
topics.response_text: Me? I'm Pete, Keeper of the Story.

topics.topic_text: I'd like to know all about your people.
topics.response_text: Wonderful! I'm sure you've noticed the mural on the wall of this hut. Shall I tell you what it all means?

topics.topic_text: Could you me tell the story of the mural again?
topics.response_text: You want to hear it again? Of course! I did a good job the first time, huh?

topics.topic_text: Goodbye.
topics.response_text: Goodbye.

topics.topic_text: Sure, I can spare the time.
topics.response_text: Excellent. Imagine - you're the first outsider ever to hear our tale! <clears throat>

topics.topic_text: Another time, maybe.
topics.response_text: If you're interested in knowing more about us, it seems like you'd be pretty amazed by the mural. Is there something else?

topics.topic_text: I'm surprised Nellis was empty when your people found it.
topics.response_text: Several atomic warheads detonated here hundreds of years ago, leaving the base highly radioactive.

topics.topic_text: How do you survive, totally cut off from the world?
topics.response_text: Nellis is a completely self-sufficient community! We draw water from Lake Mead, solar arrays provide power, and we grow our own crops!

topics.topic_text: Why did your ancestors leave the safety of a vault?
topics.response_text: So you know about the vaults! Yes, we lived in one of those. Ours was numbered 34.

topics.topic_text: What are howitzers doing at an Air Force Base?
topics.response_text: You're right, they weren't here when we discovered Nellis! We found the guns at a huge weapon depot called Area 2, many miles from here!

topics.topic_text: How has Nellis taught your people to fly?
topics.response_text: Once we restored power, we learned that some elaborate chairs we'd been sleeping in were actually virtual reality simulators.

topics.topic_text: How did you learn where to find an old bomber?
topics.response_text: Loyal found a file somewhere on the base, with magazine articles, photographs, a map, even.

topics.topic_text: That's enough history for now.
topics.response_text: All right. Is there something else you'd like to talk about?

topics.topic_text: I'm looking to make myself useful. Who needs help around here?
topics.response_text: Gosh, there's a lot of folks. Argyll's our doctor - he could use help tending to any injured we got.

topics.topic_text: Your people were willing to risk it all for freedom.
topics.response_text: And at Nellis, we found it. We haven't detonated any atomic warheads since before I was born, but otherwise it's do as you will!

topics.topic_text: Yeah, any detonation with a yield of less than a half-ton of TNT is boring.
topics.response_text: [SUCCEEDED] Exactly! We haven't detonated any atomic warheads since before I was born, but besides that, to heck with nitpicky restrictions!

topics.topic_text: Yeah, I *love* it when I throw a grenade and it goes BANG!
topics.response_text: [FAILED] Um, that's nice, but it's not really the scale of explosion that interests us...

topics.topic_text: You people are really crazy about blowing stuff up!
topics.response_text: Keep that opinion to yourself when visiting Nellis, outsider. It makes you sound ignorant.

topics.topic_text: But a little radiation didn't keep your people away!
topics.response_text: That's right! Our Geiger counter indicated that the base was radioactive, but not dangerously so. Enough time has passed.

topics.topic_text: Whereas your people had brought Geiger counters with them from the vault.
topics.response_text: [SUCCEEDED] That's exactly right! You're very knowledgeable for a sav - an outsider!

topics.topic_text: But your people were mutants, immune to the radiation!
topics.response_text: [FAILED] Uh... no. We'd just brought devices called Geiger counters with us from the vault, that's all. The radiation levels were safe.

topics.topic_text: Kind of stupid, making a radioactive scrapheap your home.
topics.response_text: For your information, our people had brought Geiger counters with them from the vault. The radiation levels here were within safe limits.

topics.topic_text: The ingenuity of your people is remarkable.
topics.response_text: Thank you. Our self-sufficiency is a point of pride.

topics.topic_text: You must cultivate soy or legumes for protein, in addition to grains.
topics.response_text: [SUCCEEDED] Indeed we do! Very impressive.

topics.topic_text: But where do you get protein? Oh my god! You're all *cannibals!*
topics.response_text: [FAILED] We are certainly not cannibals! We're not savages, like some people!

topics.topic_text: I guess poor nutrition could explain a lot of your behavior.
topics.response_text: Our nutrition is not deficient! We supplement our diet of grains and vegetables with soy and legumes for protein.

topics.topic_text: Your people are a determined bunch.
topics.response_text: Yes, there's just about nothing we won't do to get our hands on some explosive ordnance!

topics.topic_text: That howitzer battery is a monument to the grit and resolve of your people.
topics.response_text: [SUCCEEDED] Thank you so much! I'll be sure to pass that on.

topics.topic_text: You folks would sell your souls for some artillery! You just love the stuff!
topics.response_text: [FAILED] I think it would be an exaggeration to imply that our interest in explosive ordnance is at odds with our integrity...

topics.topic_text: Yeah, you people are coo-koo for things that go boom.
topics.response_text: There's nothing wrong with our interest in explosive ordnance. It's kept the savages out. Until today, at least.

topics.topic_text: Of course. You wouldn't want outsiders learning to fly.
topics.response_text: Thank you for being so understanding.

topics.topic_text: Oh, to slip the surly bonds of Earth and dance amid the soaring birds...
topics.response_text: [SUCCEEDED] That's beautiful! Yes, it's exactly like that, so free, so... words can't do it justice.

topics.topic_text: Oh, to flap one's arms and plunge bird-like headlong and skybound...
topics.response_text: [FAILED] Your attempt at poetry, is... uh, beautiful, certainly. But it doesn't really work like that. Flying, I mean.

topics.topic_text: Simulators, ha! That's a crash waiting to happen!
topics.response_text: I can see how you think that, since you don't know what you're talking about.

topics.topic_text: I look forward to seeing the old bomber fly.
topics.response_text: It'll be spectacular, won't it? You should talk to Loyal. I bet you could help.

topics.topic_text: You could attach ballast to the plane and then haul it here for repairs...
topics.response_text: [SUCCEEDED] Yes! In fact, that's exactly what Loyal has planned to do. You should go talk to him!

topics.topic_text: I guess you could start the engines underwater and hop it up onto shore...
topics.response_text: [FAILED] I'm not a mechanic, but after 300 years I don't think those engines would just start up.

topics.topic_text: Keep dreaming. That plane's never going to fly.
topics.response_text: As I said, repairing and flying the bomber is our destiny. It's that simple.

conversation.response_text: Ages ago, long before I was born, we lived underground. Everyone had guns but the overseer wouldn't let us explode anything, not even a hand grenade.
We left and wandered the wastes. There were savages with knives. We blew them up with frag mines and grenades, burned them with flamethrowers.
It was neat, but there was a downside. For every 43.6 savages we killed, we lost one of our own. We needed a new home. We needed Nellis.
Nellis, glittering like shrapnel in the desert sun. Nellis, bursting with missiles, warheads, and bombs. Nellis had waited. Just for us.
Here, we have prospered and multiplied. Here, our mighty guns destroy any savages who might try to harm us before they can even reach our gates!
Well, until... but... not saying you want to harm us or you're a savage, but... anyways.{(worried your narration has insulted the player)}
Nellis has revealed many secrets. It has taught us how to fly the bombers once based here. And it has taught us where to find one!
And that is our story so far, for this last image is our future.
To restore the bomber, to fly the open skies in armored safety, raining high-explosive ordnance upon ignorant savages - this is our destiny!
I'm pleased that you listened to the entire story! Perhaps there are details you'd like to know more about? Let me know.

description:
Pete is a 12 year-old Hispanic Male.

Pete is the Keeper of the Story at the Boomer museum inside Nellis Air Force Base. Despite his young age, Pete takes his responsibilities seriously and treats the history of the Boomers with deep respect.

Pete's Personality: Serious, dedicated, and respectful of history. Pete is mature beyond his years due to his responsibilities and expects others to treat the museum's exhibits with reverence. He can be somewhat formal in his speech and mannerisms, reflecting his role as the Keeper of the Story.

Pete's Backstory: Pete was born and raised within the walls of Nellis Air Force Base, growing up as part of the Boomer community. From a young age, he showed a keen interest in the pre-War artifacts and history preserved by the Boomers. When he was old enough, he became the apprentice to Don, the previous Keeper of the Story. For years, Pete learned from Don, absorbing the stories and history behind each exhibit in the museum. Tragically, Don was killed in an accident involving whiskey and land mines a couple of months before October 11th, 2281. Following this incident, Pete was unexpectedly promoted to the position of Keeper of the Story, a role he now takes very seriously.
